s1.p: Images typically consume 50-80% of website bandwidth, significantly impacting page load speed. Slower pages reduce user engagement, increase bounce rates, and hurt search rankings. Optimized images reduce bandwidth costs and improve accessibility for users on limited connections. Modern image optimization combines format selection, compression, responsive sizing, and lazy loading. Optimization requires balancing quality against file size—finding sweet spot for visual appeal and performance. Mobile users particularly benefit from optimized images reducing data consumption on limited plans. Image optimization is essential component of performance optimization alongside code minification and caching.

s2.p: Choose JPEG for photographs and complex images, offering excellent quality-to-file-size ratio. PNG for graphics, logos, and images requiring transparency. WebP for modern browsers where compatibility isn't critical, offering superior compression. Use progressive JPEG rendering images gradually as data arrives. Modern browsers support WebP with JPEG fallback for older browsers. SVG for icons, logos, and simple graphics providing scalability without quality loss. Animated GIF for simple animations though MP4 video often provides better compression. Choose format based on content type and browser support requirements. Format selection is first optimization step with largest impact.

s3.p: Lossy compression removes some image information, reducing file size dramatically. JPEG quality setting (typically 75-85% for web) balances quality and size. WebP lossy mode compresses 25% smaller than JPEG. Lossless compression preserves all information but provides modest size reduction. PNG lossless compression typical reduces file size 10-30%. Run lossless compression tools (PNGCrush, ImageOptim) on PNG/GIF files. Progressive rendering improves perceived performance even if overall file size remains similar. Aggressive compression below recommended levels causes visible artifacts—test before deploying to production.

s4.p: Responsive images serve different sizes to different devices—reducing unnecessary large files on mobile. HTML srcset attribute enables browsers selecting appropriate image size. CSS media queries load different images for different viewport sizes. SVG scales without quality loss across all device sizes. Serve 1x resolution for mobile (up to 750px), 2x for Retina displays (up to 1500px), and full resolution for desktop. Content delivery networks (CDNs) automatically serve optimized images to different devices. Implementing responsive images requires additional HTML or server-side logic but provides significant performance improvements for image-heavy sites.

s5.p: Lazy loading defers image loading until user scrolls near—reducing initial page load time. Below-the-fold images don't load until needed. Native HTML loading='lazy' attribute enables lazy loading without JavaScript. JavaScript libraries provide fallback for older browsers. Combine lazy loading with low-resolution placeholder images (blur-up effect) improving perceived performance. Critical above-fold images should load eagerly, while below-fold images benefit from lazy loading. Balance between performance (fewer initial requests) and user experience (unexpected delays). Lazy loading is particularly beneficial for image-heavy sites like galleries or news aggregators.

s6.p: Monitor image optimization impact using tools: Google PageSpeed Insights, WebPageTest, Lighthouse, and Chrome DevTools. Measure before and after optimization to verify improvements. Track metrics: Largest Contentful Paint (LCP), Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS), page load time, and image count. A/B test compression levels and formats determining optimal settings for your audience. Set performance budgets limiting image file sizes preventing regression. Implement continuous optimization—regularly audit and update images as new formats emerge. Performance monitoring enables data-driven decisions about optimization trade-offs.
